newsitem.title: USA: Florida theft ring exported cars to Russia.
newsitem.headline: Florida theft ring exported cars to Russia.

text.p: U.S. authorities said on Friday they had dismantled a Florida car theft ring run by Finnish nationals who exported hundreds of stolen vehicles, boats and weapons to Estonia and Russia.
Authorities said the ring reflected the dramatic growth of international car theft and the emergence of burgeoning markets for U.S. goods in the former Soviet bloc.
The thieves used a malodorous method of hiding their stolen goods -- secreting the vehicles in shipping containers lined with rotting animal hides to deter curious Customs inspectors, officials said.

"These people get pretty creative," said John Sullivan, agent-in-charge of the U.S. Customs office in West Palm Beach, Florida. "They try to do it in a way that if inspectors decided to open the container, it's so disgusting that they won't bother to inspect it."

Among the alleged leaders of the ring was a Finn who served time in a Finnish prison for the murder of his parents and brother and was wanted for questioning in connection with a Helsinki car bombing, officials said.

Suspects in the case told authorities the operation, based in the small Florida town of Lake Worth, just south of Palm Beach, sent up to 500 vehicles a year out of the United States, making it the largest theft ring of its kind in recent memory, Sullivan said.
Aided by Interpol and the Finnish National Bureau of Investigation, U.S. law enforcement agencies arrested 15 suspects and seized at least 30 vehicles worth more than $700,000, officials said.
Export to Russia was a new twist in a long-running problem in southern Florida. In the past, most stolen vehicles were shipped to Latin America.

"Because they (former Soviet Union) are entering a whole new era of development, Western-produced goods have a great deal of value," said Sullivan. "There was definitely a clear profit motive. Many times they were more than doubling the price when they sent goods overseas."
Authorities identified the ring's leaders as Pauli Juntunen, 37, of Suomussalmi, Finland; Veli Virtanen, 30, of Helsinki; and Riejo Mork, 40, of Janakkala, Finland.
Juntunen, the alleged mastermind, was arrested in March on state charges but was released from the Palm Beach County jail on bond and fled the United States a week later.

Mork and Virtanen remained in custody in Florida pending sentencing. Agents completed a roundup of other suspects about three weeks ago but did not announce the arrests until now to protect the investigation in other countries, where more arrests were expected, authorities said.

Finnish authorities sought to question Virtanen, who served seven years in a Finnish prison for the 1987 slayings of his parents and younger brother, and is wanted for questioning in a 1995 car bombing of Helsinki police headquarters and courthouse, officials said.

The ringleaders recruited local criminals to steal cars in Florida's major metropolitan areas -- Miami, Fort Lauderdale, West Palm Beach and Jacksonville -- and shipped the cars through Finland and Estonia to Russia, officials said.
One of the stolen cars, a 1991 Cadillac, turned up in the possession of an innocent high-ranking Finnish government official who had no knowledge it was stolen, U.S. agents said.
The ring also dealt in jet skis, boats, car parts, construction equipment, tools, weapons and narcotics.

The Chicago-based National Insurance Crime Bureau said the export of stolen vehicles for sale in former Soviet bloc countries was a relatively new phenomenon, though authorities had recently uncovered a major theft operation shipping cars to Poland.
